subject: Re: I'd like to be able to write the prefixes com- and con- as contractions
msgSnippet: Page #21 of Kingsley Read manual details a partial solution to your question. For words where com- and con- are not stressed, the o is omitted. This
messageBody:
Page #21 of Kingsley Read manual details a partial solution to your question. For words where "com-" and "con-" are not stressed, the "o" is omitted. This makes "km-" and "kn-," which are very easy to write longhand.

Once a "com-" or "con-" are stressed, though, the "o" should be written out. There is no 'easy' way to write "com-" and "con-" in one pen stroke, if this is what you are implying. Quikscript is semi-cursive, not completely cursive. Page #13 of the manual emphasizes this point.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "cossyrosario" <cossyrosario@...> wrote:
>
> I have made good progress in QuikScipt. Learned to read and write all
> 40+ characters, learned joined letters like ar, or, etc., contractions
> for words, suffixes and prefixes.
>
> I'd like to understand how to write the prefixes com- and con- which are
> found in innumerable words in the English language. Writing k and o
> together is troublesome enough, but adding the third letter is the hard
> part. Most of the other prefixes and suffixes can be written with
> characters joined to form one combined character easy to write and
> readily recognizable. Is there a simplified way of writing com- ? Would
> it be acceptable to use just k- with the hyphen to represent both com-
> and con- as contraction for the full prefix?
>
